code: # Fetch data and dates (see ?maiquetia) data(maiquetia, package = "mev") day <- seq.Date(from = as.Date("1961-01-01"),                  to = as.Date("1999-12-31"),                  by = "day") # Compute yearly maximum of daily rainfall ymax <- tapply(maiquetia, factor(substr(day, 1, 4)), max) # Creates plot by default prof <- gev.pll(param = "Nmean",          mod = c("profile", "tem"),          dat = ymax[-length(ymax)],         N = 50) # Confidence intervals confint(prof, print = TRUE) ## Point estimate for the parameter of interest psi: ## Maximum likelihood          : 174.641  ## Tangent exponential model   : 178.219  ##  ## Confidence intervals, levels : 0.025 0.975  ## Wald intervals               : 84.418 264.864  ## Profile likelihood           : 119.925 529.129  ## Tangent exponential model    : 122.415 534.336

code: library(mev) data("maiquetia", package = "mev") day <- seq.Date(from = as.Date("1961-01-01"),                  to = as.Date("1999-12-31"), by = "day") # Keep non-zero rainfall, exclude 1999 observations nzrain <- maiquetia[substr(day, 3, 4) < 99 & maiquetia > 0] gpdf <- fit.gpd(nzrain, threshold = 20) print(gpdf) ## Method: Grimshaw  ## Log-likelihood: -832.629  ##  ## Threshold: 20  ## Number Above: 216  ## Proportion Above: 0.0604  ##  ## Estimates ##   scale    shape   ## 15.5800   0.1088   ##  ## Standard Errors ##   scale    shape   ## 1.60673  0.07785   ##  ## Optimization Information ##   Convergence: successful isTRUE(all.equal(   gpd.score(gpdf$estimate, dat = gpdf$exceedances),   c(0,0), tolerance = 1e-5)) ## [1] TRUE gpdbcor <- gpd.bcor(dat = gpdf$exceedances, par = gpdf$estimate) #print the differences between MLE and bias-corrected estimates gpdf$estimate - gpdbcor ##      scale      shape  ##  0.1915284 -0.0118876

title: Penultimate approximations
text: generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution arises non-degenerate limiting distribution maxima. key property generalized extreme value distribution max-stability, meaning distribution maxima \(T \\mathbb{N}\) location-scale transform: \(F \sim \mathsf{GEV}\), exist location scale constants \(b \\mathbb{R}\) \(>0\) \(F^T(ax+b) = F(x)\). parameters new distribution easily derived: \(X_i \stackrel{\cdot}{\sim} \mathsf{GEV}(\mu,\sigma, \xi)\), \(\max\{X_1, \ldots, X_T\} \sim \mathsf{GEV}(\mu_T, \sigma_T, \xi)\) \(\mu_T = \mu - \sigma(1-T^\xi)/\xi\) \(\sigma_T = \sigma T^\xi\) \(\xi \mathbb{N}eq 0\), \(\mu_T = \mu +\sigma \log(T)\) \(\sigma_T = \sigma\) \(\xi=0\). practice, GEV fitted data partitioned \(k\) blocks sizes \(m\), assumed eequal simplicity, \(n = km\). quality generalized extreme value approximation increases block size \(m\). fixed block sizes, estimated shape parameter generally differs asymptotic counterpart discrepancy usually introduces bias one extrapolates far beyond range observed data. Let \(F(x)\) denote thrice-differentiable distribution function endpoint \(x^*\) density \(f(x)\) define \(s(x)=-F(x)\log\{F(x)\}/f(x)\). existence limit \(\xi_{\infty} = \lim_{n \\infty} s'\{b_n\}\) necessary sufficient convergence extreme value distribution \(G\), \[\begin{align*} \lim_{n \\infty} F^n(a_nx+b_n) = \exp\left\{-(1+\xi_\infty x)^{-1/\xi_\infty}\right\}=G(x). \end{align*}\] Smith (1987) shows , \(x \\{y:1+\xi_\infty y >0\}\), exists \(z\) \[\begin{align*}    \frac{-\log[F\{v+xs(v)\}]}{-\log\{F(v)\}} = \left\{1+xs'(z)\right\}^{-1/s'(z)}, \qquad v < z < v+xs(v). \end{align*}\] \(n \geq 1\), setting \(v=b_n\) \(a_n=s(b_n)\) yields \[\begin{align*}    F^n(a_nx+b_n)=\exp\left[-\left\{1+s'(z)x\right\}^{-1/s'(z)}\right] + \mathrm{O}(n^{-1}) \end{align*}\] \(z \[\min(a_nx+b_n, b_n), \max(a_nx+b_n, b_n)]\), depending support \(F\). ultimate approximation replaces \(s'(z)\) \(s'(x^*)=\xi_{\infty}\), whereas Smith (1987) suggests instead suggests taking \(s'(b_n)\), closer \(s'(a_nx+b_n)\) \(s'(x^*)\). maximum likelihood estimate shape change threshold block size increases. Consider simplicity yearly maxima arising blocking \(m=n_y\) observations per year. interested distribution maximum \(N\) years thus target roughly shape \(\xi_{Nn_y}\), estimates instead give approximately \(\xi_{n_y}\); extrapolation error arises mismatch shape values, constant observations truly max-stable. curvature \(s'\) determines stable estimates \(\xi_t\) extrapolation window increases. illustrate previous discussion looking block maximum log-normal distribution.  left panel illustrates maximum likelihood estimates parameters repeated samples log-normal distribution closer penultimate approximation limiting tail index \(\xi_{\infty}=0\). Using max-stability, get estimate distribution maximum \(Nn_y\) observations. case, penultimate shape \(m=1000\) approximately \(\xi_{1000}=0.215\), compared \(\xi_{30} \approx 0.284\), far limiting value \(\xi_{\infty}=0\). extrapolated density estimate based \(F_1^{1000/30}\), generalized extreme value density associated distribution function penultimate approximation \(F_1^{1000/30}\), \(F_1 \sim\mathsf{GEV}(a_{30}, b_{30}, \xi_{30})\). penultimate approximation \(F_2\) accurate ultimate approximation \(\mathsf{GEV}(a_{30}, b_{30}, \xi_\infty)\), short tailed. function smith.penult computes penultimate approximation parameter models R distribution assuming model family arguments dfamily, qfamily pfamily exist. returns penultimate parameters given block size quantile case threshold models. functions particularly useful simulation studies one wants obtain approximation \(F^N\) large \(N\), get approximation asymptotic distribution test statistic finite \(N\); \(\mathsf{GEV}\) penultimate approximation numerically stable certain models moments cumulants easily derived. following plot illustrates penultimate shape parameter normal distribution based threshold exceedances. finite samples, upper tail bounded, quality approximation Gumbel distribution increases \(u \\infty\), albeit slowly.  discussion restricted block maxima generalized extreme value distribution, similar results exists peaks threshold using generalized Pareto distribution. threshold exceedances, start reciprocal hazard \(r(x) = \{1-F(x)\}/f(x)\) place \(s(x)\). normalizing constants \((u, r(u))\) penultimate shape parameter generalized Pareto distribution \(r'(u)\). can relate threshold exceedances distribution maxima follows: suppose generalized Pareto distribution \(F\) fitted threshold exceedances threshold \(u\), parameters \((\zeta_u, \sigma_u, \xi)\), \(\zeta_u\) denotes unknown proportion points threshold \(u\). \(n_y\) observations per year average, \(T\)-year return level \(z_{1/T}=u+\sigma_u/\xi\{(Tn_y\zeta_u)^\xi-1\}\). take \(F^{\zeta_uTn_y}\) approximation \(T\)-year maxima distribution, conditional exceeding \(u\).
code: library(mev) set.seed(123) x  <- seq(1, 30, length = 200) fitted <- t(replicate(n = 1000,                       fit.gev(apply(                         matrix(rlnorm(30 * 100), ncol = 30), 1, max                       ),                       method = "BFGS")$est)) penult.bm.lnorm <-   mev::smith.penult(model = "bm",                     m = (m <- 30),                     family = "lnorm")  par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(5, 5, 1, 1)) hist(   fitted[, 3],   probability = TRUE,   breaks = 20,   xlab = "estimated shape",   main = "" ) segments(   y0 = -0.5,   y1 = 0,   x0 = penult.bm.lnorm$shape,   col = "red",   lwd = 2 ) segments(   y0 = -0.5,   y1 = 0,   x0 = 0,   col = "black",   lwd = 2 )  p30 <- penult.bm.lnorm x = seq(0, 100, length = 400) N <- 1000 N30 = N / 30 plot(   x,   N * exp((N - 1) * plnorm(x, log.p = TRUE)) *     dlnorm(x),   type = "l",   bty = "l",   ylim = c(0, 0.1),   xlab = "x",   ylab = "density" ) # Get parameters of maximum of N GEV maxstabp <- function(loc, scale, shape, N) {   if (!isTRUE(all.equal(shape, 0, check.attributes = FALSE))) {     mut <- loc - scale * (1 - N ^ shape) / shape     sigmat = scale * N ^ shape     return(c(       loc = mut,       scale = sigmat,       shape = shape     ))   } else{     mut <- loc + scale * log(N)     return(c(       loc = mut,       scale = scale,       shape = shape     ))   } } p30e <-   maxstabp(     loc = p30$loc,     scale = p30$scale,     shape = p30$shape,     N = N30   ) lines(   x,   evd::dgev(     x,     loc = p30e['loc'],     scale = p30e['scale'],     shape = p30e['shape']   ),   col = "red",   lwd = 2,   lty = 2 ) p30l <-   maxstabp(     loc = p30$loc,     scale = p30$scale,     shape = 0,     N = N30   ) lines(   x,   evd::dgev(     x,     loc = p30e['loc'],     scale = p30l['scale'],     shape = 0   ),   col = 1,   lty = 3,   lwd = 1 ) legend(   x = "topright",   legend = c("exact", "ultimate", "penultimate"),   col = c(1, 1, 2),   lwd = c(2, 2, 1),   bty = "n",   lty = c(1, 3, 2) ) u <- seq(0.8, 0.9999, by = 0.0001) penult <- smith.penult(family = "norm",                        method = "pot",                        u = qnorm(u)) plot(   u,   penult$shape,   bty = "l",   type = 'l',   xlab = 'quantile',   ylab = 'penultimate shape' )

title: Penultimate approximations
text: Sample observations standard Gaussian distribution \(\mathsf{}(0,1)\) \(m = 25, 50, 100, 1000\) \(k=1000\) replications. Fit generalized extreme value distribution block maxima size \(m\). Obtain estimate distribution \(m = 1000000\) observations standard Gaussian using max-stability (functions fit.gev gev.mle can useful). Plot density resulting approximations compare density true distribution \(N\phi(x)\Phi^{N-1}(x)\). Superpose density penultimate approximation \(m = 1000000\) obtained using Smith penultimate approximation (smith.penult).

title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text: Let \(\mathcal{S}\) compact subset \(\mathbb{R}^d\). de Haan spectral representation (Haan 1984) simple max-stable processes (Schlather Tawn 2003) \[Z(\boldsymbol{s}) = \max_{\\mathbb{N}} \zeta_i W_i(\boldsymbol{s}), \qquad \boldsymbol{s} \\mathcal{S},\] \(\boldsymbol{W}\) stochastic process satisfying \(\mathrm{E}\{W(\boldsymbol{s})_{+}\}=1\) \(\boldsymbol{s} \\mathcal{S}\) \(\{\zeta_i\}_{\\mathbb{N}}\) Poisson point process intensity function \(\zeta^{-2} \mathrm{d} \zeta\). Max-stable processes arise pointwise maximum infinite collection random functions \(\varphi_i = \zeta_i \boldsymbol{W}_i\). distribution function \(D\)-dimensional max-stable vector can defined terms measure \(\Lambda\), termed exponent measure, defined \(\mathbb{R}^D \setminus\{\boldsymbol{0}_D\}\) viz. \[\Pr(\boldsymbol{Z} \leq \boldsymbol{z}) = \exp\{\Lambda([-\boldsymbol{\infty}, \boldsymbol{z}]^\mathrm{c})\}, \quad \boldsymbol{z} > \boldsymbol{0}_D.\] follows max-stability exponent measure homogeneous order \(-1\).

title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text: Let \(\mathcal{F}^+\) denote set continuous non-negative non-null functions. risk functional \(\mathcal{R}:\mathcal{F}^+ \[0, \infty)\) continuous functional homogeneous order \(1\), .e., \(\mathcal{R}(tf) = t\mathcal{R}(f)\) \(f \\mathcal{F}^+\) \(t>0\). Examples include maxima, \(\mathcal{R}(f) = \max_{j=1}^D f(\boldsymbol{s}_j)\), minima, \(\mathcal{R}(f) = \min_{j=1}^D f(\boldsymbol{s}_j)\), sums \(\mathcal{R}(f) = \sum_{j=1}^D f(\boldsymbol{s}_j)\) projections \(\mathcal{R}(f) = X(\boldsymbol{s}_j)\). \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto process admits stochastic representation [Ferreira de Haan (2014)](Dombry Ribatet 2015) \[\begin{align}   \mathsf{X} = P \frac{\mathsf{S}}{\mathcal{R}(\mathsf{S})}, \end{align}\] \(P\) unit Pareto random variable survival function \(\Pr(P>x) = x^{-\alpha}\) \(x \geq 1\) stochastic process \(\mathsf{S}\), independent \(P\), sample paths \(\mathbb{S}_{\mathrm{ang}} = \{f \\mathcal{F}^+ \setminus \mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{R}}: \|f\|_{\mathrm{ang}} = 1\}\) \(\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{R}} = \{g \\mathcal{F}^+: \mathcal{R}(x)=0\}\) \(\|\cdot\|_{\mathrm{ang}}\) norm. \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes come looking limit distribution \(\mathcal{R}\)-exceedances, .e. \(\{f: \mathcal{R}(f) >u\}\) large threshold \(u\), assuming unit Frechet margins. can achieved practice standardizing margins, drawback exceedances defined transformed scale. de Fondeville (2018) lifts assumption define generalized \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes, allowing different location scale marginal parameters (common shape parameter). risk region extreme observations lie \[\begin{align*} \mathcal{}_u= \left\{f \\mathcal{F}^+ \setminus \mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{R}}: \mathcal{R} \left( \boldsymbol{\tau} \frac{f^\xi-1}{\xi}+\boldsymbol{\eta}\right) \geq u\right\}, \end{align*}\] \(\boldsymbol{\eta}\) location function \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\) scale function. probability measure \(\mathsf{Z}^*\) \(\mathcal{}_u\) \(\Lambda(\cdot)/\Lambda\{\mathcal{}_u\}\). stochastic representation generalized \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto vector \[\begin{align}     Z(\boldsymbol{s}) = \tau(\boldsymbol{s}) \frac{X(\boldsymbol{s})^{\xi}-1}{\xi}+ \eta(\boldsymbol{s}), \end{align}\] \(X(\boldsymbol{s})\) \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto process. \(\mathcal{R}\) \(\max\), finite-dimensional distributions multivariate generalized Pareto (Rootzén, Segers, Wadsworth 2018).

title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text:
original goal mev package implement algorithm Dombry, Engelke, Oesting (2016), order perform exact simulation max-stable vectors sampling extremal function turn. Since , algorithms simulating standard \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes generalized \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes added package. based accept-reject method composition sampling can slow high dimensions. Note packages RandomFields SpatialExtremes tailored spatial processes include efficient algorithms sample (log-)Gaussian components appearing Brown–Resnick extremal Student models, makes typically faster. vignette provides details parametrization models implemented mev. various functions interest simulation include rmev, workshorse simulating max-stable random vectors; rmevspec returns samples angular distribution defined respect \(l_1\) norm; rparp simulating \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes accept-reject; rparpcs simulating \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes using composition sampling, e.g. Ho Dombry (2019) rgparp simulating generalized \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto processes using accept-reject. approach available Brown–Resnick extremal Student processes computationally intensive since requires computing numerically mixture weights. However, need computed approach efficient simlating large samples, particularly cases acceptance rate low (notably \(R( oldsymbol{X})=\min_{j=1}^DX_j\)). Let’s start simulating simple max-stable random vector negative logistic model. margins unit Frechet, can verify pooling observations fitting generalized extreme value distribution sample. parameter estimates correct, probability-probability plot shows . \( oldsymbol{Z}\) max-stable vector size \(D\) standard Gumbel margins, distribution function \(G( oldsymbol{z}) = \exp[-V\{\exp( oldsymbol{z})\}]\), subset size \(J \subseteq\{1, \ldots, D\}\), variable \(Z_J=\max_{j \J} Z( oldsymbol{s}_j)\) distribution function \(H_J(z) = \exp\{-\exp(z-\mu_{J})\}\), \(\mu_J=\log\{V_J( oldsymbol{1})_{|J|})\}\) \(0 \leq \mu_J \leq \log(|J|)\). follows homogeneity exponent measure. Gabda et al. (2012) propose probability-probability plot based fitting \(\mu_J\) maximum likelihood parameter constraints set \(|J|\) stations. data obtained pooling replications max-stable field selecting subsets size \(|J|\) \( inom{D}{|J|}\) small, else limited number stations among display higher dependence maximize power test (independence special case max-stability). Uncertainty quantification performed using nonparametric bootstrap. function maxstabtest implements special case \(J=D\).  likelihood max-stable processes untractable, inference typically performed using composite likelihood. package evd includes routines bivariate setting (see fbvpot). Consider collection independent identically distributed vectors \( oldsymbol{X}\) continuous marginal distributions max-domain attraction max-stable distribution limit measure \(\Lambda\). One can transform observations \( oldsymbol{X}_i\) pseudo-uniform samples using empirical distribution function else semi-parametric estimator, \[ egin{align} \check{F}_j(x) =  egin{cases} \mathrm{}\{: y_{ij} \leq x\}/(n+1), &  x \leq u_j,\ 1-\{1-	ilde{F}_j(u_j)\}\left\{1+\hat{\xi}\left( rac{x-u_j}{\hat{	au}_j}ight)ight\}^{-1/\hat{\xi}_j}_{+}, & x >u_j. \end{cases} \end{align}\] (see spunif). can back-transform pseudo-uniform samples \(u_{ij} = \check{F}_j(y_{ij})\) unit Pareto using quantile transform, \(z_{ij}^{\mathrm{p}} = 1/1-(u_{ij})\). map random vector \( oldsymbol{Z}^{\mathrm{p}}\) pseudo-polar coordinates, \( oldsymbol{Z}^{\mathrm{p}} \mapsto (R,  oldsymbol{\Omega})\) \(\mathbb{R}^D_{+} \(0, \infty) 	imes \mathbb{S}_1\), \(\mathbb{S}_1=\{  oldsymbol{\omega} \mathbb{R}^D_{+}: \| oldsymbol{\omega}\|_1=1\}\) \(\ell_1\)-simplex. measure \(\Lambda\) factorizes product measure \(\Lambda(\mathrm{d}  oldsymbol{z}) = D \zeta^{-2}\mathrm{d} \zeta ho_1(\mathrm{d}  oldsymbol{\omega})\) angular measure \(ho_1\), probability measure satisfying moment constraint \(D\int_{\mathbb{S}_1} \omega_j ho_1(\mathrm{d}  oldsymbol{\omega})=1\) \(j=1, \ldots, D\); moment constraint holds \(ho_1\), whereas measure dependent radial measure \(\|\cdot \|_1\) (Einmahl Segers 2009). can thus create approximate sample \( oldsymbol{\omega}\) angular measure \(ho_1\) estimate distribution non-parametrically \[\hat{H}(w) = \sum_{=1}^N \hat{p}_i\mathrm{}\{\omega_i \leq w\},\] weights \(\hat{p}_i\) obtained solution either empirical Euclidean likelihood problems mean constraint Einmahl Segers (2009). Since resulting spectral distribution discrete (problematic simulations), Carvalho et al. (2013) suggest fitting Dirichlet kernel observations, parameters \(
u  oldsymbol{w}_i (=1, \ldots, D)\) subject constraint \(\|
u oldsymbol{w}_{}\|_1=1\). ’bandwidth’ tuning parameter \(
u\) chosen via cross-validation. function angmeasdir fits Euclidean likelihood returns list weights vector wts, cross-validation parameter nu \(n 	imes D\) matrix parameters Dirichlet distribution. Alternatively, can estimate limiting spectral measure pseudo-observations enforcing mean constraint using empirical likelihood, proposed Einmahl Segers (2009). function angmeas computes weights associated observations.
code: library(mev) set.seed(0) samp <- rmev(   n = 1000,   d = 5,   param = 0.1,   model = "neglog" ) fgev <- fit.gev(c(samp), show = FALSE) fgev$estimate ##       loc     scale     shape  ## 0.9954939 0.9919429 0.9867670 par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) # Test of max-stability maxstabtest(dat = samp) # Probability-probability plot plot(fgev, which = 1, main = "") samp <-   rmev(     n = 1000,     d = 3,     param = c(0.4, 0.6, 2.9, 0.1),     model = "sdir"   ) taildep(samp, method = list(eta = "betacop", chi = "betacop")) # Plot the probability weights and compute the column mean nparangmeas <- mev::angmeas(samp, th = 0.5) plot(nparangmeas$wts,       ylab = "weights",       xlab = "observation index") abline(h = 1 / nrow(nparangmeas$ang)) colSums(nparangmeas$wts * nparangmeas$ang) ## [1] 0.3333333 0.3333333 dirangmeas <- mev::angmeasdir(samp, th = 0.5)

title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text: SpatialExtremes, can use nonparametric estimates extremal coefficient goodness--fit diagnostic. following code samples data
code: coord <- 10 * cbind(runif(50), runif(50)) di <- as.matrix(dist(coord)) dat <-   rmev(     n = 1000,     d = 100,     param = 3,     sigma = exp(-di / 2),     model = 'xstud'   ) res <- extcoef(dat = dat, coord = coord) # Extremal Student extremal coefficient function XT.extcoeffun <- function(h, nu, corrfun, ...) {   if (!is.function(corrfun)) {     stop('Invalid function `corrfun`.')   }   h <- unique(as.vector(h))   rhoh <- sapply(h, corrfun, ...)   cbind(h = h, extcoef = 2 * pt(sqrt((nu + 1) * (1 - rhoh) / (1 + rhoh)), nu +                                   1)) } #This time, only one graph with theoretical extremal coef plot(   res$dist,   res$extcoef,   ylim = c(1, 2),   pch = 20,   ylab = "extremal coefficient",   xlab = "distance" ) extcoefxt <- XT.extcoeffun(   seq(0, max(res$dist), by = 0.1),   nu = 3,   corrfun = function(x) {     exp(-x / 2)   } ) lines(extcoefxt[, 'h'],       extcoefxt[, 'extcoef'],       type = 'l',       col = 'blue',       lwd = 2)

what: Generalized R-Pareto processes for functional threshold exceedances
title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text: simulate spatial generalized \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto process.  code snippet fits Brown–Resnick model power variogram simulated data model (based one replicate). parameters estimated minimizing squared distance empirical cloud pairwise conditional probability exceedance theoretical one. include geometric anisotropy analysis.
code: lon <- seq(650, 720, length = 50) lat <- seq(215, 290, length = 50) # Create a grid grid <- expand.grid(lon, lat) coord <- as.matrix(grid) dianiso <- distg(coord, 1.5, 0.5) sgrid <- scale(grid, scale = FALSE) # Specify marginal parameters `loc` and `scale` over grid eta <- 26 + 0.05 * sgrid[, 1] - 0.16 * sgrid[, 2] tau <- 9 + 0.05 * sgrid[, 1] - 0.04 * sgrid[, 2] # Parameter matrix of Huesler--Reiss # associated to power variogram Lambda <- ((dianiso / 30) ^ 0.7) / 4 # Simulate generalized max-Pareto field above u=50 set.seed(345) simu1 <- rgparp(   n = 1,   thresh = 50,   shape = 0.1,   riskf = "max",   scale = tau,   loc = eta,   sigma = Lambda,   model = "hr" ) # The same, but conditional on an exceedance at a site simu2 <- rgparp(   n = 1,   thresh = 50,   shape = 0.1,   riskf = "site",   siteindex = 1225,   scale = tau,   loc = eta,   sigma = Lambda,   model = "hr" ) #Plot the generalized max-Pareto field par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) fields::quilt.plot(grid[, 1], grid[, 2], simu1, nx = 50, ny = 50) SpatialExtremes::swiss(add = TRUE) fields::quilt.plot(grid[, 1], grid[, 2], simu2, nx = 50, ny = 50) SpatialExtremes::swiss(add = TRUE) # Value at conditioning coordinate should be greater than 50 simu2[1225] ## [1] 84.81661 lon <- seq(650, 720, length = 10) lat <- seq(215, 290, length = 10) # Create a grid grid <- expand.grid(lon, lat) coord <- as.matrix(grid) dianiso <- distg(coord, 1.5, 0.5) sgrid <- scale(grid, scale = FALSE) # Specify marginal parameters `loc` and `scale` over grid eta <- 26 + 0.05 * sgrid[, 1] - 0.16 * sgrid[, 2] tau <- 9 + 0.05 * sgrid[, 1] - 0.04 * sgrid[, 2] # Parameter matrix of Huesler--Reiss # associated to power variogram Lambda <- ((dianiso / 30) ^ 0.7) / 4 # Simulate generalized max-Pareto field above u=50 set.seed(345) simu1 <- rgparp(   n = 1000,   thresh = 50,   shape = 0.1,   riskf = "max",   scale = tau,   loc = eta,   sigma = Lambda,   model = "hr" ) extdat <- extremo(   dat = simu1,   margp = 0.9,   coord = coord,   scale = 1.5,   rho = 0.5,   plot = TRUE ) # Constrained optimization # Minimize distance between extremal coefficient from fitted variogram mindistpvario <- function(par, emp, coord) {   alpha <-     par[1]   if (!isTRUE(all(alpha > 0, alpha < 2))) {     return(1e10)   }   scale <- par[2]   if (scale <= 0) {     return(1e10)   }   a <- par[3]   if (a < 1) {     return(1e10)   }   rho <- par[4]   if (abs(rho) >= pi / 2) {     return(1e10)   }   semivariomat <-     power.vario(distg(coord, a, rho), alpha = alpha, scale = scale)   sum((2 * (1 - pnorm(     sqrt(semivariomat[lower.tri(semivariomat)] / 2)   )) - emp) ^ 2) } # constrained optimization for the parameters hin <- function(par, ...) {   c(1.99 - par[1],     -1e-5 + par[1],     -1e-5 + par[2],     par[3] - 1,     pi / 2 - par[4],     par[4] + pi / 2) } opt <- alabama::auglag(   par = c(0.5, 30, 1.5, 0.5),   hin = hin,   control.optim = list(parscale = c(0.5, 30, 1.5, 0.5)),   fn = function(par) {     mindistpvario(par, emp = extdat[, 'prob'], coord = coord)   } ) ## Min(hin):  0.49999  ## Outer iteration:  1  ## Min(hin):  0.49999  ## par:  0.5 30 1.5 0.5  ## fval =   77.37  ##   ## Outer iteration:  2  ## Min(hin):  0.3992261  ## par:  0.668296 74.8862 1.39923 0.556808  ## fval =   6.52  ##   ## Outer iteration:  3  ## Min(hin):  0.3992502  ## par:  0.668285 74.8855 1.39925 0.556807  ## fval =   6.52  ## stopifnot(opt$kkt1, opt$kkt2) # Plotting the extremogram in the deformed space distfa <- distg(loc = coord, opt$par[3], opt$par[4]) plot(   c(distfa[lower.tri(distfa)]),   extdat[, 2],   pch = 20,   col = scales::alpha(1, 0.1),   yaxs = "i",   xaxs = "i",   bty = 'l',   xlab = "distance",   ylab = "cond. prob. of exceedance",   ylim = c(0, 1) ) lines(   x = (distvec <- seq(0, 200, length = 1000)),   col = 2,   lwd = 2,   2 * (1 - pnorm(sqrt(     power.vario(distvec, alpha = opt$par[1], scale = opt$par[2]) / 2   ))) )

title: Simulation of multivariate extreme value distributions and processes
text: Simulate Gaussian random vector (using e.g. function mvrnorm package RandomFields) independent observations vectors covariance matrix \(\alpha \boldsymbol{1}_D\boldsymbol{1}_D^\top + (1-\alpha)\mathrm{diag}(\boldsymbol{1}_D)\) \(\alpha \\{0,0.25,0.5,0.75\}\). Use maxstabtest simulated data comment diagnostic plots. Simulate 100 realizaions \(\mathcal{R}\)-Pareto process risk function \(\max\) \(\min\) Brown–Resnick model power variogram function power.vario shape alpha = 1 scale = 2 grid \(\{1,2,\ldots, 4\}^2\) using rparp rparpcs. Benchmark two methods: fastest acceptance rate accept-reject? Partial sample code given :
code: grid <- as.matrix(expand.grid(1:5, 1:5)) depmat <-   power.vario(h = distg(grid, scale = 1, rho = 0),               alpha = 1,               scale = 2) / 4 # This is where composition sampling shines! samp <- rparpcs(   n = 1000,   shape = 0.1,   riskf = "min",   Lambda = depmat,   model = "br" ) #rparp is computationally intensive with "min" - only for samp2 <- rparp(   n = 1000,   shape = 0.1,   riskf = "max",   sigma = depmat,   model = "hr" )

title: Multivariate Extreme Value Distributions
text: R-package perform simulations multivariate extreme value models. package also includes routine functions univariate analysis, notably threshold selection diagnostics, optimization, bias-correction tangent exponential model approximations, non-parametric spectral measure estimation using empirical likelihood methods, etc. install Github, use installing devtools. Notes tutorial given EVA 2019 can obtained lbelzile.github.io/mevtuto
code: devtools::install_github("lbelzile/mev")

title: Wadsworth's univariate and bivariate exponential threshold diagnostics — W.diag
code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(123) W.diag(rexp(1000), model = 'nhpp', k = 20, q1 = 0) # Parameter stability only W.diag(abs(rnorm(5000)), model = 'nhpp', k = 30, q1 = 0, plots = "PS") xbvn <- mvrnorm(6000, mu = rep(0, 2), Sigma = cbind(c(1, 0.7), c(0.7, 1))) # Transform margins to exponential manually xbvn.exp <- -log(1 - pnorm(xbvn)) W.diag(apply(xbvn.exp, 1, min), model = 'exp', k = 30, q1 = 0) #rate parametrization W.diag(xbvn, model = 'exp', k = 30, q1 = 0) W.diag(apply(xbvn.exp, 1, min), model = 'invexp', k = 30, q1 = 0) #inverse rate parametrization }

title: Parametric estimates of \(\bar{\chi}\) — chibar
text: function fits generalized Pareto distribution minima Pareto variates, using representation $$\Pr(\min(X) > x) = \frac{L(x)}{x^{1/\eta}},$$ \(\bar{\chi}=2\eta-1\). data transformed unit Pareto scale generalized Pareto variable fitted minimum. parameter \(\eta\) corresponds shape latter. confidence intervals can based either delta-method, profile likelihood tangent exponential model approximation.

title: Parametric estimates of \(\bar{\chi}\) — chibar
code: chibar(dat, confint = c("delta", "profile", "tem"), qu = 0, level = 0.95)

title: Parametric estimates of \(\bar{\chi}\) — chibar
text: dat \(n\) \(d\) matrix multivariate observations confint string indicating type confidence interval. qu percentile level threshold. Default observations. level confidence level required

title: Parametric estimates of \(\bar{\chi}\) — chibar
text: named vector length 3 containing point estimate, lower upper confidence intervals

title: Parametric estimates of \(\bar{\chi}\) — chibar
code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(765) # Max-stable model, chibar = 1 dat <- evd::rbvevd(n = 1000, dep = 0.5) chibar(dat, 'profile', qu = 0.5) s <- seq(0.05,1, length = 30) chibar_est <- t(sapply(s, function(keep){chibar(dat, 'delta', qu = keep)})) matplot(s, chibar_est, type = 'l', col = c(1, 2, 2),  lty = c(1, 2, 2),  ylab = expression(bar(chi)), xlab = 'p') abline(h = 1, lty = 3, col = 'grey') # Multivariate normal sample, chibar = 0 - strong asymptotic independence at penultimate level dat <- mvrnorm(n = 1000, mu = c(0, 0), Sigma = cbind(c(1, 0.75), c(0.75, 1))) chibar(dat, 'tem', q = 0.1) chibar_est <- t(sapply(s, function(keep){chibar(dat, 'profile', qu = keep)})) matplot(s, chibar_est, type = 'l', col = c(1, 2, 2),  lty = c(1, 2, 2),  ylab = expression(bar(chi)), xlab = 'p') abline(h = 1, lty = 3, col = 'grey') }

code: set.seed(123) xdat <- evd::rgpd(1000, loc = 0, scale = 2, shape = 0.5) par <- fit.egp(xdat, thresh = 0, model = 'egp3')$par p <- c(1/1000, 1/1500, 1/2000) #With multiple thresholds th <- c(0, 0.1, 0.2, 1) opt <- tstab.egp(xdat, th, model = 'egp1')  egp.retlev(xdat, opt$thresh, opt$par, 'egp1', p = p)  opt <- tstab.egp(xdat, th, model = 'egp2', plots = NA) egp.retlev(xdat, opt$thresh, opt$par, 'egp2', p = p)  opt <- tstab.egp(xdat, th, model = 'egp3', plots = NA) egp.retlev(xdat, opt$thresh, opt$par, 'egp3', p = p)

title: Exponent measure for multivariate generalized Pareto distributions — expme
code: if (FALSE) { # Extremal Student Sigma <- stats::rWishart(n = 1, df = 20, Sigma = diag(10))[, , 1] expme(z = rep(1, ncol(Sigma)), par = list(Sigma = cov2cor(Sigma), df = 3), model = "xstud") # Brown-Resnick model D <- 5L loc <- cbind(runif(D), runif(D)) di <- as.matrix(dist(rbind(c(0, ncol(loc)), loc))) semivario <- function(d, alpha = 1.5, lambda = 1) {   (d / lambda)^alpha } Vmat <- semivario(di) Lambda <- Vmat[-1, -1] / 2 expme(z = rep(1, ncol(Lambda)), par = list(Lambda = Lambda), model = "br", method = "mvPot") Sigma <- outer(Vmat[-1, 1], Vmat[1, -1], "+") - Vmat[-1, -1] expme(z = rep(1, ncol(Lambda)), par = list(Lambda = Lambda), model = "br", method = "mvPot") }

title: Extremal index estimators based on interexceedance time and gap of exceedances — ext.index
text: iteratively reweighted least square procedure based gaps exceedances \(S_n=T_n-1\) model first fitted non-zero gaps, rescaled unit exponential scale. slope theoretical quantiles normalized gap exceedances \(b=1/\theta\), intercept \(=\log(\theta)/\theta\). , estimate extremal index based \(\hat{\theta}=\exp(\hat{}/\hat{b})\). weights chosen way reduce influence smallest values. estimator exploits dual role \(\theta\) parameter mean interexceedance time well mixture proportion non-zero component. maximum likelihood based independence likelihood rescaled gap exceedances, namely \(\bar{F}(u_n)S(u_n)\). score equation equivalent quadratic equation \(\theta\) maximum likelihood estimate available closed form. validity requires however condition \(D^{(2)}(u_n)\) apply; checked user beforehand. warning emitted effective sample size less 50 observations.

title: Estimators of the extremal coefficient — extcoef
text:
Smith estimator: suppose \(Z(x)\) simple max-stable vector (.e., unit Frechet marginals).  \(1/Z\) unit exponential \(1/\max(Z(s_1), Z(s_2))\) exponential  rate \(	heta = \max\{Z(s_1), Z(s_2)\}\).  extremal index pair can therefore calculated using reciprocal mean. Schlather Tawn estimator: likelihood naive estimator pair two sites \(\) $$ \mathrm{card}\left\{ j: \max_{\} X_i^{(j)} ar{X}_i)>z ight\} \log(	heta_A) - 	heta_A \sum_{j=1}^n \left[ \max \left\{z, \max_{\} (X_i^{(j)} ar{X}_i)ight\}ight]^{-1},$$ \( ar{X}_i = n^{-1} \sum_{j=1}^n 1/X_i^{(j)}\) harmonic mean \(z\) threshold unit Frechet scale. search maximum likelihood estimate every pair \(\)  restricted interval \([1,3]\). binned version extremal coefficient cloud also returned. Schlather estimator self-consistent. Schlather Tawn estimator includes special case Smith estimator censor data (p = 0) standardize observations harmonic mean. F-madogram estimator non-parametric estimate based stationary process \(Z\); extremal coefficient satisfies $$	heta(h)= rac{1+2
u(h)}{1-2
u(h)},$$ $$
u(h) =  rac{1}{2} \mathsf{E}[|F(Z(s+h)-F(Z(s))|]$$ implementation uses complete pairs calculate relative ranks. estimators coded plain R computations optimized. estimation time can therefore significant large data sets. missing observations, routine fmadogram SpatialExtremes package prefered noticeably faster. data typically consist max-stable vectors block maxima. Smith Schlather--Tawn estimators require unit Frechet margins; margins standardized unit Frechet scale, either parametrically nonparametrically unless standardize = FALSE. method = "parametric", parametric GEV model fitted column dat using maximum likelihood  estimation transformed back using probability integral transform. method = "nonparametric",  using empirical distribution function. latter default, appreciably faster.

text: Schlather, M. J. Tawn (2003). dependence measure multivariate spatial extremes, Biometrika, 90(1), pp.139--156. Cooley, D., P. Naveau P. Poncet (2006). Variograms spatial max-stable random fields,  : Bertail P., Soulier P., Doukhan P. (eds) Dependence Probability Statistics. Lecture Notes Statistics, vol. 187. Springer, New York, NY R. J. Erhardt, R. L. Smith (2012), Approximate Bayesian computing spatial extremes, Computational Statistics Data Analysis, 56, pp.1468--1481.

title: Estimators of the extremal coefficient — extcoef
code: if (FALSE) { coord <- 10*cbind(runif(50), runif(50)) di <- as.matrix(dist(coord)) dat <- rmev(n = 1000, d = 100, param = 3, sigma = exp(-di/2), model = 'xstud') res <- extcoef(dat = dat, coord = coord) # Extremal Student extremal coefficient function  XT.extcoeffun <- function(h, nu, corrfun, ...){   if(!is.function(corrfun)){     stop('Invalid function \"corrfun\".')   }   h <- unique(as.vector(h))   rhoh <- sapply(h, corrfun, ...)   cbind(h = h, extcoef = 2*pt(sqrt((nu+1)*(1-rhoh)/(1+rhoh)), nu+1)) } #This time, only one graph with theoretical extremal coef plot(res$dist, res$extcoef, ylim = c(1,2), pch = 20); abline(v = 2, col = 'gray') extcoefxt <- XT.extcoeffun(seq(0, 10, by = 0.1), nu = 3,                             corrfun = function(x){exp(-x/2)}) lines(extcoefxt[,'h'], extcoefxt[,'extcoef'], type = 'l', col = 'blue', lwd = 2) # Brown--Resnick extremal coefficient function BR.extcoeffun <- function(h, vario, ...){   if(!is.function(vario)){     stop('Invalid function \"vario\".')   }   h <- unique(as.vector(h))   gammah <- sapply(h, vario, ...)   cbind(h = h, extcoef = 2*pnorm(sqrt(gammah/4))) } extcoefbr<- BR.extcoeffun(seq(0, 20, by = 0.25), vario = function(x){2*x^0.7}) lines(extcoefbr[,'h'], extcoefbr[,'extcoef'], type = 'l', col = 'orange', lwd = 2)  coord <- 10*cbind(runif(20), runif(20)) di <- as.matrix(dist(coord)) dat <- rmev(n = 1000, d = 20, param = 3, sigma = exp(-di/2), model = 'xstud') res <- extcoef(dat = dat, coord = coord, estimator = "smith") }

title: Extended generalised Pareto families of Naveau et al. (2016) — extgp
text: extended generalized Pareto families proposed Naveau et al. (2016) retain tail index distribution compliant theoretical behavior extreme low rainfall. five proposals, first one equivalent GP distribution. type 0 corresponds uniform carrier, \(G(u)=u\). type 1 corresponds three parameters family, carrier \(G(u)=u^\kappa\). type 2 corresponds three parameters family, carrier \(G(u)=1-V_\delta((1-u)^\delta)\). type 3 corresponds four parameters family, carrier $$G(u)=1-V_\delta((1-u)^\delta))^{\kappa/2}$$. type 4 corresponds five parameter model (mixture type 2, \(G(u)=pu^\kappa + (1-p)*u^\delta\)

title: Pairwise extremogram for max-risk functional — extremo
code: if (FALSE) { lon <- seq(650, 720, length = 10) lat <- seq(215, 290, length = 10) # Create a grid grid <- expand.grid(lon,lat) coord <- as.matrix(grid) dianiso <- distg(coord, 1.5, 0.5) sgrid <- scale(grid, scale = FALSE) # Specify marginal parameters `loc` and `scale` over grid eta <- 26 + 0.05*sgrid[,1] - 0.16*sgrid[,2] tau <- 9 + 0.05*sgrid[,1] - 0.04*sgrid[,2] # Parameter matrix of Huesler--Reiss # associated to power variogram Lambda <- ((dianiso/30)^0.7)/4 # Regular Euclidean distance between sites di <- distg(coord, 1, 0) # Simulate generalized max-Pareto field set.seed(345) simu1 <- rgparp(n = 1000, thresh = 50, shape = 0.1, riskf = "max",                 scale = tau, loc = eta, sigma = Lambda, model = "hr") extdat <- extremo(dat = simu1, margp = 0.98, coord = coord,                   scale = 1.5, rho = 0.5, plot = TRUE)  # Constrained optimization # Minimize distance between extremal coefficient from fitted variogram mindistpvario <- function(par, emp, coord){ alpha <- par[1]; if(!isTRUE(all(alpha > 0, alpha < 2))){return(1e10)} scale <- par[2]; if(scale <= 0){return(1e10)} a <- par[3]; if(a<1){return(1e10)} rho <- par[4]; if(abs(rho) >= pi/2){return(1e10)} semivariomat <- power.vario(distg(coord, a, rho), alpha = alpha, scale = scale)   sum((2*(1-pnorm(sqrt(semivariomat[lower.tri(semivariomat)]/2))) - emp)^2) }  hin <- function(par, ...){   c(1.99-par[1], -1e-5 + par[1],     -1e-5 + par[2],     par[3]-1,     pi/2 - par[4],     par[4]+pi/2)   } opt <- alabama::auglag(par = c(0.7, 30, 1, 0),                        hin = hin,                         fn = function(par){                           mindistpvario(par, emp = extdat[,'prob'], coord = coord)}) stopifnot(opt$kkt1, opt$kkt2) # Plotting the extremogram in the deformed space distfa <- distg(loc = coord, opt$par[3], opt$par[4]) plot(c(distfa[lower.tri(distfa)]), extdat[,2], pch = 20, col = scales::alpha(1,0.1), yaxs = "i", xaxs = "i", bty = 'l',      xlab = "distance", ylab= "cond. prob. of exceedance", ylim = c(0,1)) lines(x = (distvec <- seq(0,200, length = 1000)), col = 2, lwd = 2,       2*(1-pnorm(sqrt(power.vario(distvec, alpha = opt$par[1], scale = opt$par[2])/2)))) }

text: data data vector. model integer ranging 0 4 indicating model select (see extgp). method string; either 'mle' maximum likelihood, 'pwm' probability weighted moments, . init vector initial values, comprising \(p\), \(\kappa\), \(\delta\),\(\sigma\),\(\xi\) (order) optimization. parameters may appear depending model. censoring numeric vector length 2 containing lower upper bound censoring; censoring=c(0,Inf) equivalent censoring. rounded numeric giving instrumental precision (rounding data), default 0. confint logical; confidence interval returned (percentile bootstrap). R integer; number bootstrap replications. ncpus integer; number CPUs parallel calculations (default: 1). plots logical; whether produce histogram density plots.

title: Fit an extended generalized Pareto distribution of Naveau et al. — fit.extgp
text: different models include following transformations: model 0 corresponds uniform carrier, \(G(u)=u\). model 1 corresponds three parameters family, carrier \(G(u)=u^\kappa\). model 2 corresponds three parameters family, carrier \(G(u)=1-V_\delta((1-u)^\delta)\). model 3 corresponds four parameters family, carrier $$G(u)=1-V_\delta((1-u)^\delta))^{\kappa/2}$$. model 4 corresponds five parameter model (mixture type 2, \(G(u)=pu^\kappa + (1-p)*u^\delta\)

title: Fit an extended generalized Pareto distribution of Naveau et al. — fit.extgp

title: Bias correction for GEV distribution — gev.bcor
text: Method subtractsolves $$\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} + b(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$$ \(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\), using first order term bias expansion given gev.bias. alternative use Firth's modified score find root $$U(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}})-(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}})b(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}),$$ \(U\) score vector, \(b\) first order bias \(\) either observed Fisher information. routine uses MLE (bias-corrected) starting values proceeds find solution using root finding algorithm. Since bias-correction valid \(\xi < -1/3\), solution unbounded return vector NA solution exist .

title: Bias correction for GEV distribution — gev.bcor

title: Bias correction for GP distribution — gpd.bcor
text: Method subtract solves $$\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} + b(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$$ \(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\), using first order term bias expansion given gpd.bias. alternative use Firth's modified score find root $$U(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}})-(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}})b(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}),$$ \(U\) score vector, \(b\) first order bias \(\) either observed Fisher information. routine uses MLE starting value proceeds find solution using root finding algorithm. Since bias-correction valid \(\xi < -1/3\), solution unbounded return vector NA bias correction exist .

title: Bias correction for GP distribution — gpd.bcor

title: Profile log-likelihood for the generalized Pareto distribution — gpd.pll
text: psi parameter vector profile (unidimensional) param string indicating parameter profile mod string indicating model. See Details. mle maximum likelihood estimate \((\psi, \xi)\) parametrization \(\psi \neq \xi\) \((\sigma, \xi)\) otherwise (optional). dat sample vector excesses, unless threshold provided (case user provides original data) m number observations interest return levels. Required args values 'VaR' 'ES' N size block take maxima. Required args Nmean Nquant. p tail probability, equivalent \(1/m\). Required args quant. q level quantile N-block maxima. Required args Nquant. correction logical indicating whether use spline.corr smooth tem approximation. threshold numerical threshold fit generalized Pareto distribution plot logical; profile likelihood displayed? Default TRUE ... additional arguments output call Vfun mode='tem'.

title: Profile log-likelihood for the generalized Pareto distribution — gpd.pll
text: list components mle: maximum likelihood estimate psi.max: maximum profile likelihood estimate param: string indicating parameter profile std.error: standard error psi.max psi: vector parameter \(psi\) given psi pll: values profile log likelihood psi maxpll: value maximum profile log likelihood family: string indicating "gpd" threshold: value threshold, default zero addition, mod includes tem normal:maximum likelihood estimate standard error interest parameter \(psi\) r:values likelihood root corresponding \(\psi\) q:vector likelihood modifications rstar:modified likelihood root vector rstar.old:uncorrected modified likelihood root vector tem.psimax:maximum tangent exponential model likelihood addition, mod includes modif tem.mle: maximum tangent exponential modified profile log likelihood tem.profll: values modified profile log likelihood psi tem.maxpll: value maximum modified profile log likelihood empcov.mle: maximum Severini's empirical covariance modified profile log likelihood empcov.profll: values modified profile log likelihood psi empcov.maxpll: value maximum modified profile log likelihood

title: Profile log-likelihood for the generalized Pareto distribution — gpd.pll
text: three mod available profile (default), tem, tangent exponential model (TEM) approximation modif penalized profile likelihood based \(p^*\) approximation proposed Severini. latter, penalization based TEM empirical covariance adjustment term.

title: Tangent exponential model approximation for the GP distribution — gpd.tem
code: set.seed(123) dat <- evd::rgpd(n = 40, scale = 1, shape = -0.1) #with plots m1 <- gpd.tem(param = 'shape', n.psi = 50, dat = dat, plot = TRUE)   if (FALSE) { m2 <- gpd.tem(param = 'scale', n.psi = 50, dat = dat) m3 <- gpd.tem(param = 'VaR', n.psi = 50, dat = dat, m = 100) #Providing psi psi <- c(seq(2, 5, length = 15), seq(5, 35, length = 45)) m4 <- gpd.tem(param = 'ES', dat = dat, m = 100, psi = psi, correction = FALSE) mev:::plot.fr(m4, which = c(2, 4)) plot(fr4 <- spline.corr(m4)) confint(m1) confint(m4, parm = 2, warn = FALSE) m5 <- gpd.tem(param = 'Nmean', dat = dat, N = 100, psi = psi, correction = FALSE) m6 <- gpd.tem(param = 'Nquant', dat = dat, N = 100, q = 0.7, correction = FALSE) }

title: Interpret bivariate threshold exceedance models — ibvpot
code: y <- evd::rgpd(1000,1,1,1) x <- y*rmevspec(n=1000,d=2,sigma=cbind(c(0,0.5),c(0.5,0)),model='hr') mod <- evd::fbvpot(x,threshold = c(1,1),model = 'hr',likelihood ='censored') ibvpot(mod, c(20,20)) #> Bivariate POT model: hr  #> Thresholds: 1 1  #> Extreme levels of interest (x,y): 20 20  #> P(X > x) = 0.01737574  #> P(Y > y) = 0.02125021  #> P(X > x, Y > y) = 0.005673096  #> P(X > x) * P(Y > y) = 0.0003692381  #> P(Y > y | X > x) = 0.3264953  #> P(X > x | Y > y) = 0.2669666

title: Exact simulations of multivariate extreme value distributions — rmev
text: n number observations d dimension sample param parameter vector logistic, bilogistic, negative bilogistic extremal Dirichlet (Coles Tawn) model. Parameter matrix Dirichlet mixture. Degree freedoms extremal student model. See Details. asy list asymmetry parameters, rmvevd, \(2^d-1\) vectors size corresponding power set d, sum one constraints. sigma covariance matrix Brown-Resnick extremal Student-t distributions. Symmetric matrix squared  coefficients \(\lambda^2\) Husler-Reiss model, zero diagonal elements. model multivariate extreme value distributions, users can choose 1-parameter logistic negative logistic, asymmetric logistic negative logistic, bilogistic, Husler-Reiss, extremal Dirichlet model (Coles Tawn) Dirichlet mixture. Spatial models include Brown-Resnick, Smith, Schlather extremal Student max-stable processes. alg algorithm, either simulation via extremal function ('ef') via spectral measure ('sm'). Default ef. weights vector length m m mixture components. Must sum one vario semivariogram function whose first argument must distance. Used provided conjunction coord sigma missing coord d k matrix coordinates, used input variogram vario parameter Smith model. grid TRUE, unique entries supplied. grid Logical. TRUE coordinates two-dimensional grid points (spatial models). dist symmetric matrix pairwise distances. Default NULL. ... additional arguments vario function

title: Exact simulations of multivariate extreme value distributions — rmev
text: vector param differs depending model log: one dimensional parameter greater 1 alog: \(2^d-d-1\) dimensional parameter dep. Values recycled needed. neglog: one dimensional positive parameter aneglog: \(2^d-d-1\) dimensional parameter dep. Values recycled needed. bilog: d-dimensional vector parameters \([0,1]\) negbilog: d-dimensional vector negative parameters ct, dir, negdir, sdir: d-dimensional vector positive ()symmetry parameters. dir negdir, \(d+1\)  vector consisting d Dirichlet parameters last entry index regular variation \((-\min(\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_d), 1]\) treated shape parameter xstud: one dimensional parameter corresponding degrees freedom alpha dirmix: d m-dimensional matrix positive ()symmetry parameters pairbeta, pairexp: d(d-1)/2+1 vector parameters, containing concentration parameter coefficients pairwise beta, lexicographical order e.g., \(\beta_{12}, \beta_{13}, \ldots\) wdirbs, wexpbs: 2d vector d concentration parameters followed d Dirichlet parameters Stephenson points multivariate asymmetric negative logistic model given e.g. Coles Tawn (1991) valid distribution function dimension \(d>3\) unless additional constraints imposed parameter values. implementation mev uses construction asymmetric logistic distribution (see vignette). match bivariate implementation rbvevd. dependence parameter evd package Husler-Reiss distribution can recovered taking Brown--Resnick model  \(2/r=\sqrt(2\gamma(h))\) \(h\) lag vector sites \(r=1/\lambda\) Husler--Reiss.

code: if (FALSE) { #Brown-Resnick, Wadsworth and Tawn (2014) parametrization D <- 20L coord <- cbind(runif(D), runif(D)) semivario <- function(d, alpha = 1.5, lambda = 1){0.5 * (d/lambda)^alpha} Lambda <- semivario(as.matrix(dist(coord))) / 2 rparpcs(n = 10, Lambda = Lambda, model = 'br', shape = 0.1) #Extremal Student Sigma <- stats::rWishart(n = 1, df = 20, Sigma = diag(10))[,,1] rparpcs(n = 10, Sigma = cov2cor(Sigma), df = 3, model = 'xstud') }

title: Simulation of generalized Huesler-Reiss Pareto vectors via composition sampling — rparpcshr
text: Sample generalized Pareto process associated Huesler-Reiss spectral profiles. Huesler-Reiss Pareto vectors, matrix Sigma utilized build \(Q\) viz. $$Q = \Sigma^{-1} - \frac{\Sigma^{-1}\mathbf{1}_d\mathbf{1}_d^\top\Sigma^{-1}}{\mathbf{1}_d^\top\Sigma^{-1}\mathbf{1}_d}.$$ location vector m Sigma parameters underlying log-Gaussian process.

title: Simulation of generalized Huesler-Reiss Pareto vectors via composition sampling — rparpcshr
text: n d matrix observations

title: Simulation of generalized Huesler-Reiss Pareto vectors via composition sampling — rparpcshr
text: Ho, Z. W. O C. Dombry (2019), Simple models multivariate regular variations   Huesler-Reiss Pareto distribution, Journal Multivariate Analysis (173), p. 525-550, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmva.2019.04.008

title: Simulation of generalized Huesler-Reiss Pareto vectors via composition sampling — rparpcshr
code: D <- 20L coord <- cbind(runif(D), runif(D)) di <- as.matrix(dist(rbind(c(0, ncol(coord)), coord))) semivario <- function(d, alpha = 1.5, lambda = 1){(d/lambda)^alpha} Vmat <- semivario(di) Sigma <- outer(Vmat[-1, 1], Vmat[1, -1], '+') - Vmat[-1, -1] m <- Vmat[-1,1] if (FALSE) { samp <- rparpcshr(n = 100, u = c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10)),           alpha = seq(0.1, 1, length = 20), Sigma = Sigma, m = m) }

title: Smith's third penultimate approximation — smith.penult.fn
text: Let \(F\), \(f\) denote respectively distribution density functions define function \(\phi(x)\)  $$\phi(x)=-\frac{F(x)\log F(x)}{f(x)}$$ block maxima. sequence loc corresponds \(b_n\) otherwise, defined solution \(F(b_n)=\exp(-1/n)\). scale given \(a_n=\phi(b_n)\), shape \(\gamma_n=\phi'(b_n)\). returned call smith.penult. threshold exceedances, \(b_n\) replaced sequence thresholds \(u\) take instead \(\phi(x)\) reciprocal hazard function \(\phi(x)=(1-F(x))/f(x)\). cases distribution function maximum domain attraction Gumbel distribution, \(\rho\) possibly undetermined \(\epsilon\) can equal \(\phi(b_n)\phi''(b_n)\). distributions maximum domain attraction Gumbel distribution class N, also possible abstract \(\rho\) parameter substituting function \(H_{\rho}\) \(x^3/6\) without affecting rate convergence. can done setting mdaGumbel=TRUE function call.

title: Smith's third penultimate approximation — smith.penult.fn
text: third penultimate approximation yield valid distribution function whole range original distribution, rather valid neighborhood true support distribution maxima/threshold exceedance. function handles standard failure (decreasing distribution function negative densities), oscillatory behaviour necessarily captured. inherent method can resolved `' evaluating functions \(F\) \(f\) faulty points.

title: Smith's third penultimate approximation — smith.penult.fn
text: Smith, R.L. (1987). Approximations extreme value theory. Technical report 205, Center Stochastic Process, University North Carolina, 1--34.

title: Smith's third penultimate approximation — smith.penult.fn
code:
#Normal maxima example from Smith (1987) m <- 100 #block of size 100 p <- smith.penult(family='norm',    ddensF=function(x){-x*dnorm(x)}, method='bm', m=m, returnList=FALSE) approx <- smith.penult.fn(loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=p[3],    eps=p[3]^2+p[3]+p[2]^2, mdaGumbel=TRUE, method='bm') x <- seq(0.5,6,by=0.001) #First penultimate approximation plot(x, exp(m*pnorm(x, log.p=TRUE)),type='l', ylab='CDF', main='Distribution of the maxima of
 100 standard normal variates') lines(x, evd::pgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=0),col=2) lines(x, evd::pgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=p[3]),col=3) lines(x, approx$F(x),col=4) legend(x='bottomright',lty=c(1,1,1,1),col=c(1,2,3,4),    legend=c('Exact','1st approx.','2nd approx.','3rd approx'),bty='n')  plot(x, m*dnorm(x)*exp((m-1)*pnorm(x,log.p=TRUE)),type='l', ylab='Density', main='Distribution of the maxima of
 100 standard normal variates') lines(x, evd::dgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=0),col=2) lines(x, evd::dgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=p[3]),col=3) lines(x, approx$f(x),col=4) legend(x='topright',lty=c(1,1,1,1),col=c(1,2,3,4),  legend=c('Exact','1st approx.','2nd approx.','3rd approx'),bty='n')   #Threshold exceedances par <- smith.penult(family = "norm", ddensF=function(x){-x*dnorm(x)}, method='pot', u=4, returnList=FALSE) approx <- smith.penult.fn(loc=par[1], scale=par[2], shape=par[3],  eps=par[3]^2+par[3]+par[2]^2, mdaGumbel=TRUE, method='pot') x <- seq(4.01,7,by=0.01) #Distribution function plot(x, 1-(1-pnorm(x))/(1-pnorm(par[1])),type='l', ylab='Conditional CDF', main='Exceedances over 4
 for standard normal variates') lines(x, evd::pgpd(x, loc=par[1], scale=par[2], shape=0),col=2) lines(x, evd::pgpd(x, loc=par[1], scale=par[2], shape=par[3]),col=3) lines(x, approx$F(x),col=4)  #Density plot(x, dnorm(x)/(1-pnorm(par[1])),type='l', ylab='Conditional density', main='Exceedances over 4
 for standard normal variates') lines(x, evd::dgpd(x, loc=par[1], scale=par[2], shape=0),col=2) lines(x, evd::dgpd(x, loc=par[1], scale=par[2], shape=par[3]),col=3) lines(x, approx$f(x),col=4)

code: #Threshold exceedance for Normal variables qu <- seq(1,5,by=0.02) penult <- smith.penult(family = "norm", ddensF=function(x){-x*dnorm(x)},    method = 'pot', u = qu) plot(qu, penult$shape, type='l', xlab='Quantile',    ylab='Penultimate shape', ylim=c(-0.5,0))  #Block maxima for Gamma variables - #User must provide arguments for shape (or rate) m <- seq(30, 3650, by=30) penult <- smith.penult(family = 'gamma', method = 'bm', m=m, shape=0.1) plot(m, penult$shape, type='l', xlab='Quantile', ylab='Penultimate shape')   #Comparing density of GEV approximation with true density of maxima m <- 100 #block of size 100 p <- smith.penult(family='norm',    ddensF=function(x){-x*dnorm(x)}, method='bm', m=m, returnList=FALSE) x <- seq(1, 5, by = 0.01) plot(x, m*dnorm(x)*exp((m-1)*pnorm(x,log.p=TRUE)),type='l', ylab='Density', main='Distribution of the maxima of\n 100 standard normal variates') lines(x, evd::dgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=0),col=2) lines(x, evd::dgev(x,loc=p[1], scale=p[2], shape=p[3]),col=3) legend(x = 'topright',lty = c(1,1,1,1), col = c(1,2,3,4),    legend = c('exact', 'ultimate', 'penultimate'), bty = 'n')

Ignoring latter, several estimators \(\eta\) can defined. unit Pareto margins, \(\eta\) shape parameter can estimated fitting generalized Pareto distribution high threshold. exponential margins, \(\eta\) scale parameter maximum likelihood estimator latter Hill estimator. methods based peaks--threshold user can choose pointwise confidence confint obtained likelihood ratio test statistic ("lrt") Wald statistic ("wald").

title: Coefficient of extremal asymmetry — xasym
text: Let U, V uniform random variables define partial extremal dependence coefficients \(\varphi_{+}(u) = \Pr(V > U | U > u, V > u)\), \(\varphi_{-}(u) = \Pr(V < U | U > u, V > u)\) \(\varphi_0(u) = \Pr(V = U | U > u, V > u)\) Define $$ \varphi(u) = \frac{\varphi_{+} - \varphi_{-}}{\varphi_{+} + \varphi_{-}}$$ empirical likelihood estimator, derived max-stable vectors unit Frechet margins, $$\frac{\sum_i p_i (w_i \leq 0.5) - 0.5}{0.5 - 2*\sum_i p_i(0.5-w_i)*(w_i \leq 0.5)}$$ \(p_i\) empirical likelihood weight observation \(\) \(w_i\) pseudo-angle associated first coordinate.

title: Coefficient of extremal asymmetry — xasym
text: Semadeni, C. (2020). Inference Angular Distribution Extremes, PhD thesis, EPFL, . 8168.
